sub_topic: The investigation of the properties of the Higgs boson in different production modes
message_1: "What are the differences in the properties of the Higgs boson when produced through gluon-gluon fusion compared to vector-boson fusion in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC)?"
message_2:
The Higgs boson, a fundamental particle in the Standard Model of particle physics, can be produced through different processes in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Two of the main production mechanisms are gluon-gluon fusion (ggF) and vector-boson fusion (VBF). While the Higgs boson itself has the same properties regardless of the production mechanism, there are differences in the production processes and the experimental signatures associated with each mechanism.

1. Production cross-section: Gluon-gluon fusion is the dominant production mechanism for the Higgs boson at the LHC, with a much larger production cross-section compared to vector-boson fusion. This means that the probability of producing a Higgs boson through ggF is higher than through VBF.

2. Initial state particles: In gluon-gluon fusion, as the name suggests, two gluons from the colliding protons interact to produce the Higgs boson. In vector-boson fusion, two quarks from the colliding protons emit vector bosons (W or Z), which then interact to produce the Higgs boson.

3. Kinematic properties: The kinematic properties of the events produced in ggF and VBF are different. In VBF, the two quarks that emit the vector bosons typically result in two high-energy jets that are well-separated in rapidity. In ggF, the Higgs boson is typically produced with higher transverse momentum, and the associated jets are less energetic and less separated in rapidity.

4. Background processes: The background processes that can mimic the Higgs boson signal are different for ggF and VBF. For example, in VBF, one of the main backgrounds is the production of a Z boson in association with two jets, while in ggF, the main backgrounds are the production of a top quark-antiquark pair and the production of a Higgs boson in association with a vector boson.

5. Sensitivity to new physics: The ggF and VBF production mechanisms can have different sensitivities to new physics beyond the Standard Model. For example, the presence of new heavy particles that couple to gluons could enhance the ggF production rate, while new particles that couple to vector bosons could affect the VBF production rate.

In summary, while the Higgs boson itself has the same properties regardless of the production mechanism, the experimental signatures and background processes associated with gluon-gluon fusion and vector-boson fusion are different, which can have implications for the search strategies and the sensitivity to new physics at the LHC.
